commentBody: No, not that Gary Larson.

I liked this Wednesday puzzle a lot. It felt fresh and livey.

(But is "Spell it ar" a familiar phrase?)

A lot to love in this puzzle. I personally love these puzzles with a clever revealer that switch around common phrases, and SPELLITOUT was a great one. I liked the crossing of CHAMPSATTHEBOUT (the best theme entry) and TYSON. I like misdirects on the first clue, and the one for COIFS was great; I also loved the muffler clue. A new clue for OBOE (that I didn‚Äôt know but could guess). A nice level of the difficulty for a Wednesday and just a great well-rounded puzzle.

This was a top notch Wednesday, with a theme that wasn‚Äôt obvious to me until I got the revealer.  I loved POUTYPARTY.  There were some nice non theme clues too, such as [works on a muffler] for KNITS and [just about anything in a string] for CATTOY (funny and true).

When I saw the Ali Frazier clue, without any crosses I was champing at the bit, and I proudly plunked in thrillainmanila only to be chagrined to find out that wasn‚Äôt it at all and I was out of luck.

Tell Mr Holmes to use his indoors voice? Top of the line product at the plumbing supply store? NO SHOUT, SHERLOCK TRUE GROUT And if you‚Äôd like a laugh about the USES of a cell phone, check this from 2005: https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/12/05/getting-started

Here‚Äôs one that almost works except you have to change another letter:

Recruiter for late night comedy?

SNL SCOUT

Whaddya know?
OBOE
3 days in a row
Themed Monday-Wednesday puzzles always appreciated, keep them coming.

I support all the positive comments‚Ä¶ fun, effervescent puzzle.

I don‚Äôt speak much German, but friends told me the phrase JFK used meant he claimed to be a jelly donut, because of the ‚Äúein‚Äù, which should have been omitted.

42 across with "See 50 down" as some obscure reference to the Mafia while crossing NIK (as in neatnik???) and KAOS (More obscure trivia) was definitely not my favorite to fill out the center, basically had to just guess at the end there
But ‚Ä¶ like, is it THE Gary Larsen?

My 11-year-old son was looking over my shoulder and told me the answer to 3-down was IOUS (duh, mom [*eye-roll*]). I argued with him that a Wednesday puzzle wouldn‚Äôt have something that obvious & erased it once he left the room. Oops. re-entered it with the crosses 10 minutes later.

More evidence of the crossword conspiracy:
14A in the main puzzle, and 5A in the mini, are the SAME WORD!  (UBoat)
Coincidence..

I don't know.

Oh - I enjoyed the puzzle and the theme.

Tonight I reached a streak of 3653 gold stars.  No arbitrary number at all, just an annual milestone...I'm sure by now, you've figured it out that Dec. 17, 2015--the Obama era--was the last time I had a blue star.

And looking at my solve in the Archive, I don't even know why.  I apparently "Revealed square" where ANDY, clued as the tennis player Roddick, and OYS, clued as exclamations of exasperation, crossed.  I'm sure ANDY was a gimme, and OYS seems obvious...who knows what made me do that?  All I know is that if I hadn't done that, I would have reached this milestone months earlier.

But only months, not years, because sometime not long before that, I had just switched to solving in the NYT interface.  I had previously been solving on a platform called Puzzazz, and on Across Lite before that.  For a time, I switched from one platform to another often. So my streak couldn't have even been a year longer.

But at the time, the idea of a streak was something new, and I guess it didn't matter that much to me back then.  After all, why would I have revealed a square that was easily gettable?

I hope that ten years hence, I'll still have a streak.  Heck, I hope I'll still be doing crosswords...or anything!  Who knows what can happen in ten years, but I hope to report on 12/17/35 that my streak is 7305!
thought the theme was kinda meh, myself.

For anyone who wants an accurate distinction between ‚Äúchamping at the bit‚Äù and ‚Äúchomping at the bit‚Äù: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=BMPfKq2_XgQ No mare splitting of hairs. Hope I didn‚Äôt rein on your parade. Certainly not my intention to stirrup trouble.

Killed by trivia.
Tough for a Wednesday.

That was fun.
Thanks Gary and Doug
I nominate for Wednesday PoY.

POUTYPARTY blew the lid off, and after that it was just OU kidding.  Not hard, but engaging, and I finished it smiling, which is always preferable to pouting.

Thanks Doug and Gary, hope to see you arOUnd again soon.
Yamaha product seemed like an odd clue for OBOE. I know Yamaha makes a lot of different products, but I did not know it made oboes.

I think I spent more time trying to understand the revealer, than the solve. 

Simple enough to figure out eventually.  But ‚ÄúYamaha product‚Äù and ‚Äúa smartphone has lots of these‚Äù and ‚Äúmuffler worker‚Äù were nice misdirects for a Wednesday.

Loved the punniness of this one. I giggled my way through the themers. The comments didn‚Äôt disappoint either. So many clever punsters among the ranks here. Just waiting to see what Mike the Punster from Munster will create for us ü§ì
Also waiting for the poster who asks almost daily if this is the same Gary Larson. It will be hysterical if they don‚Äôt ask today of all days‚Ä¶
I feel like ive seen OBOE so much recently lol
I thought 45-Across was ‚ÄúSHOUT IN THE OCEAN‚Äù at first, and was very shocked that NYT would allow such language, upon doing the ‚ÄúIT‚Äù/‚ÄúOUT‚Äù replacement‚Ä¶..

It was an U-BOOT. Went with that for a little while. 

The challenge for the solver is to find something you like every day. Andrzej will find the things not to like. He‚Äôs good at that üòÄ and mostly I agree with him. MEGA-ULTRA????

I liked the PEST clue best probably because I didn‚Äôt get the IT-OUT trick until I read Sam‚Äôs column.  

My loss. 

Thanks.
At what point does a ‚Äúmisdirect‚Äù become simply a ‚Äúbad clue‚Äù?
Fun üëç
Loved it! Worthy entries, clever cluing, nice and challenging for a Wednesday. I'm totally satisfied with this one.

I found this puzzle much easier than yesterday's.
That's not a complaint. I'm just sayin.

Loved it!
And such nice, friendly and positive coments.

My first thought was "can't be IOUS, can it?", but I believe 3D has a pun in it, as in why would a stud buckle down and study? Because he owes money, say student loans. 

Everybody else got that, right?

In my book, that puts it in the "very funny" category, not lame at all.
Is this the same Doug Peterson who's a football coach?

I meant to offer this YouTube link yesterday, but got busy, and never back to the Comments. Luckily, today, I get a second chance: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iSBgyWPr99I&list=RDiSBgyWPr99I&start_radio=1

[Just about anything on a string] 
For CAT TOY 
Is TRUE TO LIFE.

It was fun guessing at the theme answers and revealer, but what I‚Äôm remembering even more are two strange thoughts that hit me as I looked over the completed grid:
‚Ä¢	The cross of CAT TOY and a backward ASP had me imagining how it would go if these two creatures actually crossed paths.
‚Ä¢	OZ is right in the middle of OOZE, making it an ‚Äúoohs and ahs‚Äù word.

Answers I loved: FATHOM and HAM UP.
Clue I adored, perfect in every way: [Group of grumps sitting around kvetching].

Plus, a little nerd-love for the two rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilaps REPEL and KNITS.

And so a good time was had by me.  Thanks, Doug and Gary!

The history of Nippon Gakki Co., Ltd.--aka the Yamaha Corporation--is a fascination example of organic corporate growth and diversification. Founded in 1887 by Torakusu Yamaha as a manufacturer of  reed organs (for which there was little demand in fin-de-si√®cle Japan), the company soon transitioned to building pianos. From there, the development went:

organs-->pianos-->guitars-->other musical instruments, beginning with trumpets-->today's OBOE
                            \-->phonographs-->other audio equipment-->semiconductors-->synthesizers, esp. the DX-7
                            \-->(WW II wartime) wooden airplane propellers (the same fine woodworking skills used to make piano soundboards)-->complete airplanes-->(post-WW II) motorcycles*-->other sporting vehicles, including golf carts and personal watercraft
                            \-->archery equipment-->other sporting goods, esp. golf clubs.

This is, of course, over-simplification, and I'm sure I missed a few; but throughout, the corporate logo has been three interlocked musical tuning forks, styled as a Japanese heraldic *mon*.

A long and winding path to the C1 which happily sits by my living room window!

*in 1955, the motor division was spun off as a separate corporation, but it still used the same logo.
My memory isn't great, but this has to be the best Wednesday of 2025. Great theme and clueing throughout!
idk i had POUTY PANTS for an embarrassingly long time

Really clever puzzle. Typical Wednesday workout for me but tumbling to the trick was a big turning point. That's always a nice touch. Two thumbs up. Puzzle find today - a clever one with an unusual kind of theme. A Sunday from October 16, 1994 by Raymond Hamel with the title "Out of their element." Theme answers - all straightforwardly clued: FLYINTHEOINTMENT CASTLEINTHEAIR CATCHERINTHERYE PIEINTHESKY BATSINTHEBELFRY DOGINTHEMANGER BULLINACHINASHOP Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/16/1994&g=97&d=A ....
I liked this one! Very clever, and I loved a lot of the clues.
Many thanks to Frank Bruni, for providing the answer to 38 Down, in his column today!
My appreciation of today's puzzle *owes* a lot to the answer at 3D.   I gotta splout now.  Many thanks.

Very clever theme, just right for a Wednesday. Kudos for CHAMPSATTHEBOUT, a fine themer and properly derived from "champs at the bit", which is so often incorrectly rendered as "chomps at the bit". Surely "pity party" is quite familiar, but I wonder about "spit in the ocean". Is this still in use? I think of it as rather old. Not sure why.

Too bad that KNITS, with the non-thematic IT, couldn't have been worked out of the grid. I'm guessing that the constructors tried to do so, but were unable to remove that IT without losing TRUETOLIFE and basically redoing the entire right side of the grid.

Seemed like a fine Wednesday puzzle to me.

Oh, and another puzzle find, inspired by a number of comments about ICH. ICHBINEINBERLINER was an answer once - in a Sunday puzzle from August 12, 2001 by Nancy Nicholson Joline with the title: "In crowd." In that puzzle that answer included three rebus squares, specifically: ICHB(IN)E(IN)BERL(IN)ER And... that puzzle had 22 'IN' rebus squares. Some other answer examples: STR(IN)GBIK(IN)IS F(IN)GERPR(IN)TS SP(IN)ET(IN)GL(IN)G THERA(IN)(IN)SPA(IN) AFTERD(IN)NERM(IN)TS And there were lots more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/12/2001&g=23&d=A ...
For all of you who thought of SHOUT phrases, I want you to know that I will be childishly giggling for the rest of the day.
The theme is clever and fun, but my favorite clue is 13 Down Fly by night...or by day.
It took me a while staring at SPELL IT OUT before it suddenly clicked. Brilliant. So far it‚Äôs been 3 for 3 this week with awesome puzzles. I‚Äôm hoping for a great thurs with some rebus action.

OBOE seems to be encroaching on OREO‚Äôs territory lately. 

CASA NOSTRA will be‚Ä¶displeased‚Ä¶

What you might get after biting into a Carl‚Äôs Jr. burger you brought home from the drive-thru?


TAKEOUTONTHECHIN

Ah, a good, fun puzzle to come home to.
And back home to daily walks on the beach, loving on every dog we meet. Which is why my mind went to the dogs, giggling at "barked" orders being CUR-T.

While visiting up north, the local paper included the USA Today version of puzzle mania, a special weekend section of anagrams, sudokus, and giant crosswords. Anyone else pick up that puzzle section? Eric, any reviews?
Mostly at the NYT Wednesday level, with very little wordplay in the cluing. As I solved, I often thought of what the reaction here would be to some of the answers. One of the puzzles had a secondary theme of Star Trek references.

I did order a copy of this year's NYT Puzzle Mania, but haven't started it yet.

My brother has been subjecting the whole family to this joke for like a week, so now I'm inflicting it on everyone here.

What did Howard Cosell say when he chopped down his Christmas tree?









Down goes Frazier!

What a fun Wednesday! I agree with those who think this was one of the best of the year. I love to start my day with giggles. (Shouts and giggles?) And I can see myself using that "ou" combo all day...we'll see how many people do the puzzle by who gets what I'm doing!

Happy 4th candle tonight!

Thrilled to see [CHAMPSATTHEBIT] in the puzzle . My father grilled it into me at a young age long before the internet. 

He liked to point out incorrect grammar. "Me" vs "I" was another of his bugaboos. That made listening to songs on the single in-dash speaker AM/FM radio on car rides an adventure. That and no air conditioning. 

He did point out that one should keep such knowledge to oneself lest one be thought a pompous jerk. 

The incorrect use of travesty is probably my own bugaboo. I don't recall seeing it in a puzzle of late.

I admit I greedily wanted at least one more themer.  
My first sight of the grid--with those roadblocks to keep the different sections from assisting our solve in the next-door areas....daunting.  

The only way I get to see SNL is on clips posted by FBk fans....but there have been some grand "Updates" lately.  The best part is watching Jost and CHE trying not to burst out laughing...

Poindexter?

And I must say, I've never heard "SPIT IN THE OCEAN"....why would anyone do that...or think of that...?  "Needle in a haystack"  or "Beat a dead horse" or "Coals to Newcastle"  weren't good enough?

Wonderful revealer. Ultra fun theme. (I would expect no less from the duo who invented Charlie Brown.)

Sam outdid herself on today's photo. O Corbin! My Captain!


A little disappointing to see the editors swallow the official line on who the bad guys are in Get Smart.

[Promote one's body art salon?]








TOUT FOR TAT

This was fun! Loved the theme. Loved the rest as well. One of these days I will remember that it‚Äôs AMOCO - not Amaco! That‚Äôs almost always my error. üò°ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Thanks, Gary & Doug! Happy Wednesday, y‚Äôall.
tough corners on this one, especially the starting. Good puzzle.

Two literal LOLs for me today:

1. The theme reveal after having worked through the three anchors, and
2. "Basically anything on a string" answer

Bravo, gents!

What an ingenious revealer!!  I was looking for a change in sound explanation of the theme answers -- and couldn't come up with one.  But it's a change in spelling explanation -- and I couldn't guess it.  In three words, it explains everything!

Was 27D meant to be a trap?  I confidently wrote in EMOTE, which is always the answer to "overplay for the audience" and it was beautifully confirmed by the "genre" for Glorilla.  EMO, right?  Wrong!  Whoever she is, she's RAP, not EMO -- and the answer to 27D is HAM UP.  What a write-over mess that section of my grid is!

A word about 8D.  I've lived in NYC my entire life and I've never seen ANTS "marching" in the sidewalk cracks.  Not even one ant.  ANTS in NYC prefer Central Park, just as I do.  If you want ANTS, that's where you go to find them.

A playful and nicely executed theme, I thought.
I was loving this from the get go! Decided to do it clock-wise from 1A, no breaks, just for giggles. Lots of great cluing to otherwise standard fills. Wednesday all the way. Thanks for the fun!

You know what makes a great CAT TOY? A wine cork. Seriously, throw one down the hall, and see what happens. It mostly rolls, but then it flips end over end, and cats love the randomness of that, like it's living prey. Also, and excuse to buy wine.
Another solid puzzle, makes several great grids in a row!

"The comment you are looking for is currently unavailable."

Was it something I said? :)

It was the thread that started off with someone complaining about the clue and answer for 3D "What makes a stud become studious?"

ULTRA-fun Wednesday -- I loved every IOTA of it!  Thank you, Gary and Doug!

The clue for 28D, however, would be questioned by true Mainers. Bibs are provided (upon request) for tourists eating lobster. If bibs become required for CRABS, a shellfish etiquette lesson should accompany the order. My Maryland friends may disagree! ü¶ÄüòÇ

Happy Wednesday, all!
This made me purrrrrr....esp "Fly by night ... or by day."  Thanks for the wordy party, Gary and Doug!
I'll be taking a break from posting I think. My original post has been taken down for no reason. Ditto my post disapproving of that action. I will not be treated like this.

Not a fan. Been playing the NYT crossword for 5 years and still hate the use of spoonerisms and ESPECIALLY when there is no reasonable way one would detect that they are being used. 

Add to this some crosses that were questionable and the solve becomes miserable. CRABS? I don‚Äôt think people eat CRABS. They eat crab. No ‚Äús‚Äù

There were others as well but I am done with this puzzle.
Show of hands from all the teens-at-heart who got the Poindexter clue right away!  ü§£
one of the best I've played in a long time! fun, clever, and just the right amount of difficulty for a Wednesday
Weak theme with some sketchy cluing. QUEST was probably my least favorite, centerpiece was an odd descriptor. Onwards

I had I-O-U-S at first, then took it out thinking, "that'd be too obv-ious..." I actually went back and forth a few times with it until I finally filled that corner. COIFS and FATHOM tripped me up a bit, as did OBOE for something by Yamaha- my mind went to right away to motorcycles and wouldn't let go... I liked CUPS though, it's my sign :)

I thought there was a rule that the clue should not contain the answer. IOUS is obviously a violation and too easy for any day of the week.

 I guess next we‚Äôll see ‚Äúwhat makes the weak a weakling‚Äù clued for LING or ‚Äúwhat makes the smart the smartest?‚Äù for EST.

That was loads of fun! I love themes like this that play around with expressions. And I thought this was a really good one! Kind of wish there would have been one more theme answer. Many good Mr X, some I fell for, some I didn't. All were fun! I can't really pick a favorite today. POUTYPARTY really made me laugh though, so I guess if I had to pick a favorite...

I generally like all of the puzzles to varying degrees, but this one definitely feels a cut above.
It was really fun!  Thank you.

I managed to finish this in about 30 minutes and even then, even after reading the article, the theme is still a challenge. I'm HIGHLY skeptical!
Try this sentence "I'll have the crabs" now again "I'll have the crab". See where I'm going with this.

Lots of fun. Took me some time to see the trick but I got there. 
Once again, the complaints from some solvers leave me wondering why they do puzzles at all. It‚Äôs entertainment, not a required task. I do them for fun, to learn new things, and to reassure myself that my brain is still firing on all‚Äîor most‚Äîcylinders. Thanks Gary and Doug for an entertaining puzzle. üòÅ

My kind of humor.

Failure streak up to 8, worst since starting to do this. Today it was Oboe/Coifs/Poutyparty/Sesh/IOUs.
As usually the theme was no help, it didn‚Äôt occur to me that there Spell It Out meant anything other than just write out a plain speaking answer. I think the only time in about 60 attempts at the crossword that the theme was any help was a few days ago when it was BED in all the circled letters.
The IOUs thing particularly irritated me because I couldn‚Äôt figure out how it made sense, and reading the explanation in the column just irritated me more. I don‚Äôt like that kind of clue. Quest was also poorly clued I thought.

The rest of it was well put together, i had basically nothing after about 10 minutes but got moving and managed everything except for that top left area by about 30 minutes.

The joke I always remember is the suggestion as to what JFK would have said if he gave his speech in Hamburg.

@Strudel Dad

Or Frankfurt.

@sonnel

That's a great example of an unforced error.

But, I think forgotten in all this, is that the Germans were more than willing to accept that verbal faux pas in exchange for his visit to, and commitment for the welfare of West Germany.

The context of the times at least partially overarches the blooper, I think.

@Francis
and by todays presidential elocution standards referring to yourself as a jam donut qualifies as straight-up eloquence.

@Matt

You said it.  Not me.

@sonnel
To me as a German, "Ich bin ein Berliner" sounds ok. Not correct if I were grading a student's essay, but perfectly acceptable in spoken German. 
In Berlin, that kind of donut isn't called Berliner but Pfannkuchen ("pancake"). I bet that if the rest of Germany had called them that too, nobody would have remarked on the grammar error at all but lauded JFK for trying to speak German and even getting the pronunciation kinda right. 

My guess is, a certain other holder of the same high office might have pronounced the first word "itch".

@Veevee
yeah...like fdr...or obama...or lincoln!

@Veevee

I took years of German in high school and a semester in college, for reasons that passeth understanding.

I never once pronounced "ich" and felt that I had actually said the word as a native would.

I thought to myself, I had to choose probably the only language offered where I couldn't pronounce the most important word.  

Same with the √∂ sound.  Never once confident in a word with that sound.

@Matt
Or yesterdays.

@Steve L
Or Vienna.

@Kyle

Well I won‚Äôt argue with KAOS for those who aren‚Äôt familiar with the old show‚Äîbut COSA NOSTRA is a pretty standard phrase in these puzzles and elsewhere (usually not both in the same one!) and at least one of neatNIK or beatNIK should be familiar. True, a little crunchy for a Wednesday.
@Kyle You have to be of a certain age to appreciate ‚ÄúGet Smart.‚Äù To this day, a certain tune gets stuck in my head if I find myself going through a series of doors/openings. IYKYK
@Kyle - These clues are gimmies for us boomers.  May be unknowns for younger people.

@jennie I‚Äôm a millennial and I watched Nick-at-Nite. We know what ‚ÄúGet Smart‚Äù is. 

I actually thought the word ‚Äúchaos‚Äù was spelled ‚Äúkaos‚Äù as a kid, from watching the show.

@Sandra

That's actually a great point, about millennials watching re-runs.

That wasn't really available to my generation when we were young.  There wasn't the vast reservoir of older movies and songs.  A few black-and-white movies that could only be shown in theaters, records that were barely playable...

Maybe that's something to be excited about (against everything else)--humans can draw culture so readily from the contributions of previous generations. 

I mean, it's been about 60 years since the Beatles. 60 years before *that* was the turn of the century.

@MB

I'm curious whether some tough puzzle has ever forced you to look up an answer that you couldn't solve.
@Steve L Incredible streak! Congratulations!

@Steve L

Do you really not find maintaining a streak a strain on your life? I can't imagine living the quite laid back life I'm enjoying while striving to keep a crossword streak going. Of course, you're one of the best solvers here, so getting a gold star is much easier and faster for you than it is for me, which must be a factor.

@Dan

Short answer: No; when I was less proficient in pre-electronic days, I just didn't finish.

I've been solving for over 40 years now.  My earliest solves, of course, were erasable pen on paper, so in those days, an unknown answer simply remained unsolved.  

In those early days, you checked the next day's paper for the solution. Sometimes, I had one letter wrong, but I didn't really care. There was no one to impress. There was no "community," unless your friends were also solvers. (Rex Parker started in 2006; Wordplay in 2008.)

But in order to check an unknown answer while solving, you had to literally be in a library.  And even then, it would have been cumbersome, and in some cases, impossible.

By the time the online solving rolled around, I was generally completing all my puzzles. I wouldn't have looked up an answer anyway; not finishing still didn't bother me, and looking things up (once the internet showed up) seemed to me like cheating. (I don't feel that way about newbies incorporating lookups into their solve if they prefer to do so, but I do feel that if you look things up, a gold star isn't the same.)

By the time I switched to the NYT interface in 2015, I was solidly figuring things out on my own. I realized that constructors want you to solve their puzzles, and what Rex called a Natick wasn't that common at all.

I now feel that I can solve anything the NYT throws at me (especially since they seem to be getting easier). But I probably just jinxed myself.

@Andrzej

I find that ending the day with the crossword (given that it shows up here at 10 pm most days) is a very relaxing way to segue into bedtime.

With the advent of DVRs and streaming, there's usually no need to be in front of the TV at 10:00, and in baseball season, most games are over (or just about to end) around that time, so it's a perfect time to solve.

And our social life is not so amazing that we're out past 10:00 most of the time.

If I can't solve at 10:00, I always solve before going to bed, even if it's 3 a.m. (That's the joy of being retired!)  It relaxes me before sleeping.

(In addition, this habit keeps me from forgetting to solve one day.)

When I'm in Europe (or Morocco, as I was in April), I am forced to solve upon waking up, which I don't like as much.

Regardless, my solve doesn't take up that much of my day.  I know some people hate seeing actual times posted, but you know what range I'm talking about. (I'll never regularly solve in the ridiculously fast times of the tournament finalists.  And neither am I aiming to.)

And as I said in my reply to Dan, I have no worry that I won't solve the puzzle, so there's no stress involved.

My life is probably as laid back as yours; maybe more so, since I'm not working anymore.  I don't feel any strain; if I did, I wouldn't keep doing it.

@K.M.C.

I don't know much about some of the topics you mentioned (and maybe some others you haven't), but the key to being good at crosswords is knowing just enough about those things you don't care about to get by solving.

Two things make you good at solving:

Reading the rest of the paper (or similarly keeping abreast of all current events, including the arts, sports, and the like), and practice (including looking up and familiarizing yourself with the things you don't know).

It's amazing how often some people complain that an answer is obscure when it has been used five times this year.

Oh, and the third thing:  Being open to learning new things.  Not disparaging pop culture, rap, sports, product names, etc., because you don't think they're worthy of being remembered.  These things are in the puzzle for a reason:  they fit.  They will fit again, and be used again.

Anyway, I can't say how unlikely it is you can have a ten-year streak (maybe better than you think).  But I can tell you for sure, you can always be a better solver.
Thanks to everyone for the congratulations!

@Candall Do you think adopting a pet is free? The first hit I got says this: All adoption donations are tax deductible. For dogs, the minimum donation is $450; puppies are $500. Some of the purebred or "designer" dogs/puppies tend to be at the higher end of the range of $600-$800. The minimum donation for most of our cats is $125 and for kittens, $175. The donation for purebreds, such as Siamese, Persian, Himalayan and other "exotic" cats, including those of mixed breed that show the dominant characteristics of a purebred, may range from $100-$200 or more. There is a spay/neuter deposit required for puppies ($200) and kittens of ($60). This is New York State law. The spay/neuter deposit is returned after the pet is spayed/neutered. Darren,
I gather you didn't make it to the revealer (60A) before you were "done with this puzzle."

@Darren

These are not Spoonerisms.  It's a vowel substitution puzzle.

The revealer at 60A tells you explicitly what to do:  SPELL IT OUT, for which the clue is [Painstakingly explain something ... or a hint to 17-, 26- and 45-Across].

So IT is spelled (or becomes) OUT, or more basically, I becomes OU.  Then "pity party" becomes POUTY PARTY; "champs at the bit" becomes CHAMPS AT THE BOUT, etc.  

Be on the lookout for this kind of revealer, and you'll know what to do next time.
@Darren I thought the same about crab with an s... it conjured something else, far from appetizing!
@Steve L So‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre NOT doing what the revealer tells us to do? And this is a good thing? Then lengths yall go to defend this‚Ä¶
@Darren, Yeah, it didn‚Äôt make sense as the revealer. Twice in a row in one week is rough.

D,
I hope you are just pretending to not understand the revealer. In case of emergency, note:

SPELL IT OUT. In the three themers, a common phrase becomes something funny when IT is spelled as OUT.

@D

We're doing exactly what the revealer says to do:  SPELL IT OUT.  

The normal phrase is PITY PARTY.  You spell the "it" of PITY as "out" and you get POUTY PARTY.

Exactly what you are supposed to do; exactly what you're supposed to get.  All three times.

The fact that this does not register with you is not the puzzle's fault, and the fact that you keep pushing back on everything that is exactly as it should be just tells me that you don't get it and don't want to get it.

If you don't like how these twists play out, maybe you need a different hobby.  Or if you like this hobby, maybe figure out why everyone else is in on the trick, and you're not.

The "rule" is that a word in the clue should not appear in the answer. The letters in the clue are not a word.

@Roberta The rule is that a whole word in the clue cannot be the answer. There's no rule that letters from a word in the clue cannot be the answer. Some clues that have solved to letters from the clue: What makes most moist? What makes Shrek shriek? What makes a pan a pain? AN I. What makes her hear? AN A. What makes God good? AN O. What makes car care? AN E. What makes a cat scat? What makes a top stop? ESS. What makes ale pale? PEE. (Eeew!) What makes a bloom blossom? ESSES. https://www.xwordinfo.com/SearchClues The only thing different with this one is that the answer is four of the word's letters, and not just one or two.

@Niall

If you've only tried 60 crosswords, you've got a lot of path in front of you to get better.  And you will, because with practice come skill and intuition.

To me, the revealer was crystal clear.  It might not have been so clear to me when I was just starting out solving in the 80s.

Eventually, you'll see things more readily and be able to anticipate the correct answers.  Keep at it!

@Niall
I'm with Steve L on this. Solving is a skill. It's not just breadth of knowledge, although that certainly helps. It's also the ability to squidge your eyes while reading the clues, so you can pick up the way the composer has skewed or even somersaulted what appears to bd ordinary English to mean something else entirely. That aha! accompanying each clue is what keeps you on course and lets you build up to the big moment when the music plays. Triumph!

@Niall

Yeah, this week has been a lot tougher than usual, IMO. That top left in this grid had me stuck for a while!

If you're interested in sticking with it, try to not always look at clue-answer as a binary ‚Äì something like IOU takes a sideways step, but then feels obvious to more seasoned solvers. 

Like @Steve L said, the more you keep at it, the more you will see patterns like these. (And I most certainly have not been solving since the 80's! More like sporadically until about four years ago; more consistently since.)

I hope you do stick with it. Good luck!
